user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_reset:
```c
void *
MHD_pool_reset (struct MemoryPool *pool,
                void *keep,
                size_t copy_bytes,
                size_t new_size)
{
  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (copy_bytes <= new_size);
  mhd_assert (copy_bytes <= pool->size);
  mhd_assert (keep != NULL || copy_bytes == 0);
  mhd_assert (keep == NULL || mp_ptr_le_ (pool->memory, keep));
  /* (keep == NULL || pool->memory + pool->size >= (uint8_t*) keep + copy_bytes) */
  mhd_assert ((keep == NULL) || \
              (pool->size >= mp_ptr_diff_ (keep, pool->memory) + copy_bytes));
#if defined(MHD_ASAN_POISON_ACTIVE) && defined(HAVE___ASAN_REGION_IS_POISONED)
  mhd_assert (NULL == __asan_region_is_poisoned (keep, copy_bytes));
#endif /* MHD_ASAN_POISON_ACTIVE && HAVE___ASAN_REGION_IS_POISONED */
  _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY (pool->memory, new_size);
  if ( (NULL != keep) &&
       (keep != pool->memory) )
  {
    if (0 != copy_bytes)
      memmove (pool->memory,
               keep,
               copy_bytes);
  }
  /* technically not needed, but safer to zero out */
  if (pool->size > copy_bytes)
  {
    size_t to_zero;   /** Size of area to zero-out */

    to_zero = pool->size - copy_bytes;
    _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY (pool->memory + copy_bytes, to_zero);
#ifdef _WIN32
    if (pool->is_mmap)
    {
      size_t to_recommit;     /** Size of decommitted and re-committed area. */
      uint8_t *recommit_addr;
      /* Round down to page size */
      to_recommit = to_zero - to_zero % MHD_sys_page_size_;
      recommit_addr = pool->memory + pool->size - to_recommit;

      /* De-committing and re-committing again clear memory and make
       * pages free / available for other needs until accessed. */
      if (VirtualFree (recommit_addr,
                       to_recommit,
                       MEM_DECOMMIT))
      {
        to_zero -= to_recommit;

        if (recommit_addr != VirtualAlloc (recommit_addr,
                                           to_recommit,
                                           MEM_COMMIT,
                                           PAGE_READWRITE))
          abort ();      /* Serious error, must never happen */
      }
    }
#endif /* _WIN32 */
    memset (&pool->memory[copy_bytes],
            0,
            to_zero);
  }
  pool->pos = ROUND_TO_ALIGN_PLUS_RED_ZONE (new_size);
  pool->end = pool->size;
  _MHD_POISON_MEMORY (((uint8_t *) pool->memory) + new_size, \
                      pool->size - new_size);
  return pool->memory;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_pool_reset:
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
...
#define mp_ptr_le_(p1, p2) (((constuint8_t*)(p1))<=((constuint8_t*)(p2)))
...
#define mp_ptr_diff_(p1, p2) ((size_t)(((constuint8_t*)(p1))-((constuint8_t*)(p2))))
...
#define _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY(pointer, size) (void)0
...
#define _MHD_POISON_MEMORY(pointer, size) (void)0
...
#define ROUND_TO_ALIGN_PLUS_RED_ZONE(n) ROUND_TO_ALIGN(n)
...
static size_t MHD_sys_page_size_ = (size_t)
#if defined(MHD_USE_PAGESIZE_MACRO_STATIC)
                                   PAGESIZE;
#elif defined(MHD_USE_PAGE_SIZE_MACRO_STATIC)
                                   PAGE_SIZE;
#else  /* ! MHD_USE_PAGE_SIZE_MACRO_STATIC */
                                   _MHD_FALLBACK_PAGE_SIZE
...
struct MemoryPool
{

  /**
   * Pointer to the pool's memory
   */
  uint8_t *memory;

  /**
   * Size of the pool.
   */
  size_t size;

  /**
   * Offset of the first unallocated byte.
   */
  size_t pos;

  /**
   * Offset of the byte after the last unallocated byte.
   */
  size_t end;

  /**
   * 'false' if pool was malloc'ed, 'true' if mmapped (VirtualAlloc'ed for W32).
   */
  bool is_mmap;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I examined the function and the related definitions for use of compiler-specific language extensions that compilers explicitly document as extensions (examples: GNU/Clang __attribute__ or __asm__ uses, GCC statement-expressions ({ ... }), typeof, nested functions, labels-as-values (&&label), __builtin_* language intrinsics used as extensions, Microsoft __declspec or inline assembler, asm goto, transparent unions as extensions, etc.). None of those constructs appear in the provided code.

Specific potentially confusing items and why they are NOT flagged as MISRA Rule 1.2 language extensions here:
- The conditional use of __asan_region_is_poisoned: this is a runtime/ASan symbol (instrumentation/runtime API), not a language extension keyword or compiler language-extension construct.
- The use of _WIN32, VirtualFree/VirtualAlloc and MEM_COMMIT/MEM_DECOMMIT etc.: these are platform/OS API calls and macros, not language extensions.
- The use of identifiers with leading underscores or double underscores (for example _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY, _MHD_POISON_MEMORY, names beginning with __): these are implementation-reserved identifiers but not language extensions per se; their usage is an identifier choice, not use of an extended language feature documented as a compiler extension.
- Preprocessor conditionals inside an initializer and line continuations (\): standard preprocessor features, not extensions.
- Casting, memmove/memset, pointer arithmetic, size_t, bool, and the other C constructs shown are part of standard C (C99 or later) and not compiler-specific extensions.
- The apparent token "constuint8_t" in the mp_ptr_le_ macro looks like a transcription/spacing typo in the supplied snippet; if present verbatim it would be a compile error, but it is not a recognized compiler language extension.

Therefore no explicit compiler language extensions (as required by MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 reporting) were found in the provided code fragment.
